item.title: Tips for making minimal music
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
TheRealJFalc:

Downtempo is pretty hard to define.

One only needs to look at exemplar artists to develop an understanding.

Zero 7, Kruder & Dorfmeister, Thievery Corporation, …

 

I subscribe to the definition provided by Ishkur on downtempo music, and that is electronic music not designed for dancing

But, that’s an over-simplification. Much of it is danceable (e.g. Tosca). It’s just not club-oriented. Although, even that said, bands like Koop (who were on the verge between Downtempo and Nu-Jazz) were popular in the Latin dance nightclubs.

At its core, it’s a chilled, smooth, soulful groove, subtly jazz, subtly funky. Sometimes there’ll be Latin influences (e.g. Thievery Corp. and Ilya), sometimes hip-hop influences (as with K&D).
Bands like Oi Va Voi will do their own take on it, blending Yiddish/Jewish music into the mix, to great effect.

item.title: Tips for making minimal music
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
DJ_La_Rocca:

I’m more than certain that minimal is basically just a kick and bassline. With random saw synths and stabs

OK, I see the disconnect now.
We should probably try to be more descriptive than using ‘minimal’ on its own.

(I think it highlights a problem with genres [and humans]. They’re used so fluidly, that it leads to misunderstandings and crossed wires like this. It’s the same problem with ‘lo-fi’ right now.)

 
That said, putting the bassline you created next to 90% of the basslines used in that mix — or something by (e.g.) Boris Brejcha — and surely you’d see that the bassline in your video doesn’t really fit that type of (EDM-style) Minimal Dance or Boris Brejcha-style Minimal Techno either.

The basslines owe much more to Techno, than EDM, which is where your bassline seems to come from.

 
I do think you’d benefit from listening more to those tracks to understand what’s going on – rather than simply taking away which instruments are present and which aren’t. As I said, that’s a very superficial understanding.
